etymology.description: semantic: 日 + phonetic: 丁; Shuowen folk etymology: 日 over 一 (sun over horizon).
etymology.interpretation: Combines the sun 日 with the phonetic 丁, linking its sound to dàn while evoking a meaning tied to daylight. Later folk analysis pictured the sun appearing over the horizon, which aligns with the sense of daybreak even if it was not the original form.

examples.chinese: 黎明将至(黎明將至)，天色将旦(天色將旦)。
examples.pinyin: Límíng jiāng zhì, tiānsè jiāng dàn.
examples.english: Dawn is approaching; the sky is about to break into day.

examples.chinese: 元旦放假一天(元旦放假一天)，大家出门游玩(大家出門遊玩)。
examples.pinyin: Yuándàn fàngjià yītiān, dàjiā chūmén yóuwán.
examples.english: New Year’s Day is a one-day holiday; everyone goes out to have fun.

examples.chinese: 一旦下雨(一旦下雨)，活动就改到室内(活動就改到室內)。
examples.pinyin: Yídàn xiàyǔ, huódòng jiù gǎi dào shìnèi.
examples.english: Once it rains, we’ll move the event indoors.
